questions.question: Mother was busy cooking for the guests who were arriving in the evening.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses. Clauses introduced by relative pronouns like who, which, that, whom and whose are subordinate clauses.

questions.question: The person who was injured in the accident needed help immediately.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses. Clauses introduced by relative pronouns like who, which, that, whom and whose are subordinate clauses.

questions.question: Whatever you learn at school will help you in the future.
questions.description: Here the clause 'whatever you learn at school' is a subordinate noun clause. Sentences that contain subordinate clauses are complex sentences.

questions.question: Alice cooked dinner and Mike tidied the rooms.
questions.description: A compound sentence consists of two or more coordinate clauses. Clauses connected by the conjunctions and, so, but, or, for, nor etc are coordinate clauses.

questions.question: I had a headache but I enjoyed the movie.
questions.description: A compound sentence consists of two or more coordinate clauses. Clauses connected by but are coordinate clauses.

questions.question: In spite of having a headache I enjoyed the movie.
questions.description: The above sentence has just one clause and hence it is a simple sentence.

questions.question: Although I had a headache, I enjoyed the movie.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses. Clauses introduced by the subordinating conjunctions though and although are subordinate clauses.

questions.question: We cancelled the picnic because of the rain.
questions.description: The above sentence has just one finite verb and hence it is a simple sentence.

questions.question: He is either a fool or a lunatic.
questions.description: Clauses connected by the coordinating conjunction 'either...or' are coordinate clauses and hence the above sentence is a compound sentence.

questions.question: I don't know whether he will arrive.
questions.description: The above sentence has one main clause and one subordinate noun clause and hence it is a complex sentence.

questions.question: You should have asked me before using my computer.
questions.description: The above sentence has just one finite verb and hence one clause. So it is a simple sentence.

questions.question: The girl who won the first prize is my neighbor's daughter.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses. Clauses introduced by relative pronouns like who, which, that, whom and whose are subordinate clauses.
